A square matrix is said to be idempotent if

children.value: A matrix that is linearly dependent (in the columns or rows) is singular and has determinant of zero. Note that any two (or three) vectors

children.value: will not be zero, although the product will be a singular matrix.
Systems of Equations in Matrix Form

children.label: Systems of Equations in Matrix Form

children.value: One of the uses of linear algebra in economics is to represent and then solve systems of equations. For instance, consider the system of two equations:

children.html: 3x1+4x2=57x1−2x2=23x_1 + 4x_2 = 5 \\ 7x_1 - 2x_2 = 23x1​+4x2​=57x1​−2x2​=2

A=(347−2),x=(x1x2),b=(52)\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 4 \\ 7 & -2 \end{pmatrix}, \quad \mathbf{x} = \begin{pmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \end{pmatrix}, \quad \mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}A=(37​4−2​),x=(x1​x2​​),b=(52​)

Ax=(347−2)(x1x2)=(3x1+4x27x1−2x2)\mathbf{A}\mathbf{x} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 4 \\ 7 & -2 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 3x_1 + 4x_2 \\ 7x_1 - 2x_2 \end{pmatrix}Ax=(37​4−2​)(x1​x2​​)=(3x1​+4x2​7x1​−2x2​​)

children.value: The original system is in fact equivalent to the matrix form:
